lines.speaker: first roman
lines.text: This will I carry to Rome.

lines.speaker: third roman
lines.text: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.
Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS with a trumpet

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: See here these movers that do prize their hours At a crack'd drachm! Cushions, leaden spoons, Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves, Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them! And hark, what noise the general makes! To him! There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius, Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take Convenient numbers to make good the city; Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste To help Cominius.

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st; Thy exercise hath been too violent for A second course of fight.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Sir, praise me not; My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well: The blood I drop is rather physical Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus I will appear, and fight.

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: Now the fair goddess, Fortune, Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman, Prosperity be thy page!

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Thy friend no less Than those she placeth highest! So, farewell.

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: Thou worthiest Marcius! Go, sound thy trumpet in the market-place; Call thither all the officers o' the town, Where they shall know our mind: away!
